Author: jm4
Content:
I'm not so sure the level of detail is an indication that he's disconnected with his own company's products. The vibe I got was that he was trying to describe to the people who build this stuff what it's actually like to be an end user. I think the whole point is that they're the ones who are disconnected and completely out of touch. I seriously doubt that Bill Gates _needs_ to download and buy Movie Maker from microsoft.com like a customer would.

Even if he is the one who is totally disconnected I thought all of his points were excellent and a perfectly accurate illustration of how Windows has gone wrong. What I'm left wondering is what's been going on there the past several years. If these critiques by Gates are something new it's a real shame for Microsoft that he didn't start sooner. If his statement that it's his job to do this every day is accurate then I'd say they have even bigger problems.

Author: edw519
Content:
Good salesman have always known that people buy with emotion and justify with logic.

Functional software that perfectly solves a customer's problem without a good user interface never makes it to the logic step. It was eliminated by the user's subconscious before the game ever began.

Author: mojuba
Content:
It's not obvious at all that "unobtrusive" coding has advantages. First of all, the line between HTML and what they call "behavior" is vague: many, if not all, presentation elements contain built-in behavior of some or other form, for example take any form element. JavaScript code that we write extends or customizes this behavior, rather than creates it from scratch.

Second, when we read raw HTML it's better to see explicitly that the behavior of a given element is customized. Even a small hint of customization in a form of a function call from within onClick, for example, would be a sign that a given element is different from the standard one.

Finally, less code always means easier to understand and easier to debug. There is no excuse for writing more, no matter how you call your technique, if there exists a simpler and clearly more concise way of implementing the same functionality.

Author: edw519
Content:
They skipped a few things.

- Receive a $1 million gift from your grandfather when you're born.

- Go to an elite private school with the same computing power as Stanford University when you're 13.

- Bully your co-founder out of his hard earned equity. Take over when he gets a life threatening illness.

- Have a mother who serves on the United Way board alongside the CEO of IBM (How's that for a network.)

- Have a lawyer father who teaches you how to resort to legal tactics when technical ones fail.

- Have a partner who commits one of the biggest blunders in business history (IBM's failure to keep DOS proprietary).

- Do whatever it takes to defeat anyone else, regardless of legal or ethical considerations, or long term effects on the industry.

Am I the only one who is sick and tired of all this "honoring" one of the biggest bandits in history? Doesn't anyone remember all the evil Microsoft has wrought upon the world? They say that history is written by the survivors, but forturately, this game is still being played.

I say let the door hit him in the butt on the way out and let the market continue to correct itself so that we may finally have the long delayed technical excellence this planet deserves.

Author: coffeeaddicted
Content: I also liked that one. But it also reminded me that I often use synaptic on Debian when I am looking for applications on my system which is rather similar to the "add/remove software" on Windows. The only place where I can do a sane search (including searching summaries what the applications actually do) and get an additional good categorization of the software.  Funny how the package manager on both sytems seems to have better information about your applications than for example the typical startup menu (which is usually a mess after a few months - also on both systems).

Title: How To Be The Next Bill Gates

Author: edw519
Content:
Not surprising at all. You reap what you sow.

This is a company built upon bullying, intimidation, skirting the law, and violating ethical practices in order to shove its monopoly down anyone and everyone's throat. Anything except technical excellence.

So the rest of us suffer until the market finds its way around the lawyers and corrects itself (as it usually does).

This memo is simply a representation of all the B.S. that must have been going on for years between sowing the seeds of arrogance and reaping the harvest of crap.
